Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Community Recovery and Colorado's Extreme Floods of 2013: Policy Learning in the Context of Resources, Coalitions, and Political Conditions

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the most damaging natural hazards, flooding annually causes billions of dollars in damage, response, and recovery losses for U.S. communities. As populations increase in flood prone areas, communities are becoming more vulnerable to floods. The responsibility for flood management has shifted from the federal to the local level and communities are now responsible for making decisions about if, how, and where to rebuild. Because of their potentially recurring nature, floods offer an opportunity for communities to learn from and adapt to these experiences with the goal of increasing resiliency through reflection, modification of former policies, and adoption of new policies. By following the response to the September 2013 floods in Colorado communities, this study will investigate how communities successfully learn from extreme events to increase resilience and decrease vulnerability to future floods. The project seeks to contribute to the fields of public policy and natural hazards research with the following objectives: to advance knowledge of policy learning in the aftermath of extreme events; to advance knowledge of disaster recovery, specifically as it relates to the role that community processes, citizens, and other stakeholders play in promoting long-term recovery and resilience; and to inform governments of lessons from flood responses to the September 2013 floods, with the goal of contributing to the effectiveness of governance in flood-affected communities.

The PIs will conduct longitudinal comparative case studies of seven Colorado communities, located in Colorado's three most severely impacted counties from the September 2013 floods. This study will follow communities through their recovery and planning process over a period of three years. Four types of data will be used to examine flood recovery processes and outcomes. First, in-depth interviews will be conducted of participants in the planning and decision process of the community at three intervals during the recovery process. Second, surveys will be conducted with a larger sample of recovery process participants than those interviewed. Third, periodic surveys of community residents will be conducted. Finally, documents related to flood recovery and demographic data will also be gathered. Combined, these data will enable both qualitative and quantitative analysis of recovery processes and stakeholder participation, extent of damage, coalition beliefs and behavior, political context, and resource availability in communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As one of the most damaging natural hazards, flooding annually causes billions of dollars in damage, response, and recovery losses for U.S. communities. As populations increase in flood prone areas, communities are becoming more vulnerable to floods. Flood management has shifted from the federal to the local level and communities are now responsible for making decisions about if, how, and where to rebuild and mitigating future flood risks. By following the response to the September 2013 floods in Colorado communities, this study investigated how communities successfully learn from extreme events to increase resilience and decrease vulnerability to future floods.

The project contributed to the fields of public policy and natural hazards research with the following objectives: to advance knowledge of policy learning and change in the aftermath of extreme events; to advance knowledge of disaster recovery, specifically as it relates to the role that community processes, the public, and other stakeholders play in promoting long-term recovery and resilience; and to inform governments of lessons from flood responses to the September 2013 floods, with the goal of contributing to the effectiveness of governance in flood-affected communities.

Dr. Crow and Dr. Albright (PIs) conducted longitudinal comparative case studies of seven Colorado communities, located in Colorado’s three most severely impacted counties from the September 2013 floods. This study followed communities through their recovery and planning process over a period of three years, drawing on multiple data sources to develop findings (interviews, surveys, and documents). Combined, these data enabled both qualitative and quantitative analysis of recovery processes and stakeholder participation, extent of damage, public and expert beliefs about flood causes and risks, coalition beliefs and behavior, and resource availability and capacity in communities.

Major findings with regard to processes and outcomes in recovery focused on both individuals and local government organizations. The following summary highlights major findings from the research (through 2018) with continued analysis and publication of findings expected.

Individuals:

  • Individuals in higher-wealth neighborhoods perceive greater future risks of flooding, compared to individuals in lower-resourced neighborhoods. Males perceived lower risk of future flooding than females.
  • Individual perception of community-level damage is linked with perception of future flood risk. Perceptions of future flood risk are also linked with respondents’ understanding of the underlying causes of the flooding.
  • The extent of damage experienced at the neighborhood and community levels can have a powerful effect on the perceptions of climate change held by the public. In turn, these beliefs about climate change are positively associated with perceptions of risks of future flooding.

Governments:

  • A greater openness in post-flood decision processes is associated with more in-depth deliberation, learning, and more substantive and frequent policy change.
  • Coalitions of stakeholders working to advocate for post-flood policy change are likely to form after emergency response is concluded, and more likely to form in communities with prior political participation and homogenous populations. Additionally, state government entities created collaborative coalitions seemingly to encourage social capital production, but these top-down coalitions do not appear to achieve the same type of policy-oriented activity and success as the organic coalitions that emerged where residents seek to advocate for policy solutions.
  • Local governments are most likely to see financial policy change focused on improving tools and processes for recovery reimbursement, construction, and intergovernmental relationships. There is not significant evidence of longer-term change towards becoming more financially resilient to disaster events.
  • Communities changed policies after the flood to varying degrees. Communities that engaged in greater depth of civic capacity-building also saw greater breadth and depth of policy change.
  • Intergovernmental relationships between state and local governments play significant roles in policy learning within local governments. States work with local governments in different capacities which result in different outcomes for local governments.

The PIs worked to disseminate project findings within academic publications and conferences as well as to the relevant stakeholders and decision-makers, thereby increasing the utility of the research findings. The PIs created a publicly available website where project data, metadata, reports, scholarly publications, and videotaped presentations are located and will be maintained in the future. The PIs also hosted a workshop designed to engage stakeholders and government professionals from the case communities and provide them with useable knowledge from project findings, including a final report of the research findings, written in lay language and aimed at helping local governments translate the research findings to policy outcomes. The PIs have engaged with local and national media on issues of floods and disaster recovery. Finally, this research project served as an opportunity to train four PhD students and several masters students on research methods and practices. Two of those PhD students are now faculty at major universities, one is a post-doctorate fellow, and another is a practitioner for a social science research organization.
